{"step_by_step_thinking": "A type 1 error, also known as a false positive, occurs when the null hypothesis is true, but is rejected in error. This means that the researchers would have incorrectly concluded that mepolizumab had a significant effect on reducing asthma exacerbations and improving markers of asthma control when in reality, it did not. This error is not dependent on the confidence interval of a study, nor is it a beta error. A beta error, or type 2 error, is when the null hypothesis is false, but is accepted in error.", "answer_choice": "A"}
